By construction, there is a direct sum decomposition of <math>V \otimes V = Sym^2(V) \oplus \bigwedge^2 V</math>. On characters, this corresponds to the fact that the sum of the last two expressions in the table is <math>\chi(s)^2</math>, the character of <math>V \otimes V</math>.

===Inner product and characters===
{{See also|Class function (algebra)|Schur orthogonality relations}}

In order to show some particularly interesting results about characters, it is rewarding to consider a more general type of functions on groups:

'''Definition (Class functions).''' A function <math>\varphi : G \to \Complex</math>  is called a '''class function''' if it is constant on conjugacy classes of <math>G</math>, i.e. 
:<math> \forall s, t \in G : \quad \varphi \left (sts^{-1} \right ) =\varphi(t).</math>
Note that every character is a class function, as the trace of a matrix is preserved under conjugation.

The set of all class functions is a <math>\Complex </math>–algebra and is denoted by <math> \Complex _{\text{class}}(G)</math>. Its dimension is equal to the number of conjugacy classes of <math>G.</math>

Proofs of the following results of this chapter may be found in [[#Literature|'''[1]''']], [[#Literature|'''[2]''']] and [[#Literature|'''[3]''']].

An [[Dot product|inner product]] can be defined on the set of all class functions on a finite group:
:<math> (f|h)_G=\frac{1}{|G|} \sum_{t\in G}f(t)\overline{h(t)} </math>
'''Orthonormal property.''' If  <math>\chi_1, \ldots ,\chi_k</math> are the distinct irreducible characters of <math>G</math>, they form an orthonormal basis for the vector space of all class functions with respect to the inner product defined above, i.e. 
* <math>(\chi_i|\chi_j)=\begin{cases} 1 \text{ if } i= j \\0 \text{ otherwise }\end{cases}.</math>
* Every class function <math>f</math> may be expressed as a unique linear combination of the irreducible characters <math>\chi_1, \ldots ,\chi_k</math>.
One might verify that the irreducible characters generate <math>\Complex _{\text{class}}(G)</math> by showing, that there exists no class function unequal to zero which is orthogonal to all the irreducible characters. To see this, for <math> \rho </math> a representation and <math>f</math> a class function, denote <math> \rho_f = \sum_g f(g)\rho (g).</math> Then for <math> \rho </math> irreducible, we have <math> \rho_f = \frac {|G|}{n} \langle f,\chi _V^{*} \rangle \in End(V)</math> from [[Dot product|Schur's lemma]]. Suppose <math> f </math> is a class function which is orthogonal to all the characters. Then by the above we have <math> \rho _f = 0 </math> whenever <math> \rho </math> is irreducible. But then it follows that <math> \rho _f = 0 </math> for all <math> \rho </math>, by decomposability. Take <math> \rho </math> to be the regular representation. Applying <math> \rho _f </math> to some particular basis element <math>g</math>, we get <math> f(g)=0 </math>.  Since this is true for all <math>g</math>, we have <math>f=0.</math>

It follows from the orthonormal property that the number of non-isomorphic irreducible representations of a group <math>G</math> is equal to the number of [[conjugacy class]]es of <math>G.</math>

Furthermore, a class function on <math>G</math> is a character of <math>G</math> if and only if it can be written as a linear combination of the distinct irreducible characters <math>\chi_j</math> with non-negative integer coefficients: if <math>\varphi</math> is a class function on <math>G</math> such that <math>\varphi=c_1 \chi_1 + \cdots + c_k \chi_k </math> where <math>c_j</math> non-negative integers, then <math>\varphi</math> is the character of the direct sum <math>c_1 \tau_1 \oplus \cdots \oplus c_k \tau_k</math> of the representations <math>\tau_j</math> corresponding to <math>\chi_j.</math> Conversely, it is always possible to write any character as a sum of irreducible characters.

The [[Dot product|inner product]] defined above can be extended on the set of all <math>\Complex</math>-valued functions <math>L^1(G)</math> on a finite group:
:<math> (f|h)_G=\frac{1}{|G|} \sum_{t\in G}f(t)\overline{h(t)} </math>
Also a [[symmetric bilinear form]] can be defined on <math>L^1(G):</math>
:<math> \langle f,h\rangle_G=\frac{1}{|G|} \sum_{t\in G}f(t)h(t^{-1}) </math>
These two forms match on the set of characters. If there is no danger of confusion the index of both forms <math>(\cdot|\cdot)_G</math> and <math> \langle\cdot|\cdot\rangle_G</math> will be omitted.

Let <math>V_1, V_2</math> be two <math>\Complex [G]</math>–modules. Note that <math>\Complex [G]</math>–modules are simply representations of <math>G</math>. Since the orthonormal property yields the number of irreducible representations of <math>G</math> is exactly the number of its conjugacy classes, then there are exactly as many simple <math>\Complex [G]</math>–modules (up to isomorphism) as there are conjugacy classes of <math>G.</math>

We define <math>\langle V_1, V_2 \rangle_G:=\dim (\text{Hom}^G(V_1,V_2)),</math> in which <math>\text{Hom}^G(V_1,V_2)</math> is the vector space of all <math>G</math>–linear maps. This form is bilinear with respect to the direct sum.

In the following, these bilinear forms will allow us to obtain some important results with respect to the decomposition and irreducibility of representations.

For instance, let <math>\chi_1</math> and <math>\chi_2</math> be the characters of <math>V_1</math> and <math>V_2,</math> respectively. Then<math> \langle\chi_1,\chi_2\rangle_G = (\chi_1|\chi_2)_G=\langle V_1, V_2 \rangle_G.</math>

Once can deduce the following from the results above, of Schur's lemma and of the complete reducibility of representations.

:'''Theorem.''' Let <math>V</math> be a linear representation of <math>G</math> with character <math>\xi.</math> Let <math>V=W_1\oplus \cdots \oplus W_k,</math> where <math>W_j</math> are irreducible. Let <math>(\tau,W)</math> be an irreducible representation of <math>G</math> with character <math>\chi.</math> Then the number of subrepresentations <math>W_j</math> which are isomorphic to <math>W</math> is independent of the given decomposition and is equal to the inner product <math>(\xi|\chi),</math> i.e. the <math>\tau</math>–isotype <math>V(\tau)</math> of <math>V</math> is independent of the choice of decomposition. We also get:
::<math>(\xi|\chi)=\frac{\dim (V(\tau))}{\dim (\tau)}=\langle V, W\rangle</math>
:and thus
::<math>\dim (V(\tau))=\dim (\tau)(\xi|\chi).</math>

:'''Corollary.''' Two representations with the same character are isomorphic. That means, that every representation is determined by its character.

With this we obtain a very handsome result to analyse representations:

{{anchor|Irreducibility criterion}} '''Irreducibility criterion.''' Let <math>\chi</math> be the character of the representation <math>V,</math> then we have <math>(\chi|\chi) \in \mathbb{N}_0.</math> And it holds <math>(\chi|\chi)=1</math> if and only if <math>V</math> is irreducible.

Therefore, using the first theorem, the characters of irreducible representations of <math>G</math> form an [[Orthonormality|orthonormal set]] on <math>\Complex _{\text{class}}(G)</math> with respect to this inner product.

:'''Corollary.''' Let <math>V</math> be a vector space with <math>\dim (V)=n.</math> A given irreducible representation <math>V</math> of <math>G</math> is contained <math>n</math>–times in the [[#Left- and right-regular representation|regular representation]]. That means, that if <math>R</math> denotes the regular representation of <math>G</math> we have: <math> R \cong \oplus (W_j)^{\oplus\dim (W_j)},</math> in which <math>\{W_j|j\in I\}</math> is the set of all irreducible representations of <math>G</math> that are pairwise not isomorphic to each other.

In terms of the group algebra this means, that <math>\Complex [G]\cong\oplus_{j}\text{End}(W_j)</math> as algebras.

As a numerical result we get: 
:<math>|G|=\chi_R(e)=\dim (R)=\sum_j\dim \left ((W_j)^{\oplus(\chi_{W_j}|\chi_R)} \right )=\sum_j(\chi_{W_j}|\chi_R)\cdot\dim (W_j)=\sum_j\dim (W_j)^2,</math>
in which <math>R</math> is the regular representation and <math>\chi_{W_j}</math> and <math>\chi_R</math> are corresponding characters to <math> W_j</math> and <math> R,</math> respectively. It should also be mentioned, that <math>e</math> denotes the neutral element of the group.

This formula is a necessary and sufficient condition for all irreducible representations of a group up to isomorphism. It provides us with the means to check whether we found all irreducible representations of a group up to isomorphism.

Similarly, by using the character of the regular representation evaluated at <math>s\neq e,</math> we get the equation:
:<math> 0=\chi_R(s)=\sum_j\dim (W_j)\cdot\chi_{W_j}(s).</math>

Using the description of representations via the convolution algebra we achieve an equivalent formulation of these equations:

The '''Fourier inversion formula''':
:<math>f(s)=\frac{1}{|G|}\sum_{\rho \text{ irr. rep. of } G}\dim (V_\rho)\cdot\text{Tr}(\rho(s^{-1})\cdot \hat{f}(\rho)).</math>
In addition the '''Plancherel formula''' holds:
:<math>\sum_{s\in G}f(s^{-1})\psi(s)=\frac{1}{|G|}\sum_{\rho\,\, \text{ irred.} \text{ rep.}\text{ of } G}\dim (V_{\rho})\cdot\text{Tr}(\hat{f}(\rho)\hat{h}(\rho)).</math>
In both formulas <math>(\rho, V_\rho)</math> is a linear representation of a group <math>G, s\in G</math> and <math>f, h \in L^1(G).</math>

The corollary above has an additional consequence:

:'''Lemma.''' Let <math>G</math> be a group. Then the following is equivalent:
:* <math>G</math> is [[Abelian Group|abelian]].
:* Every function on <math>G</math> is a class function.
:* All irreducible representations of <math>G</math> have degree <math>1.</math>

==The induced representation==
{{Main|Induced representation}}

As was shown in the section on [[#Properties|properties of linear representations]], we can, by restricting to a subgroup, obtain a representation of a subgroup starting from a representation of a group. Naturally we are interested in the reverse process: Is it possible to obtain the representation of a group starting from a representation of a subgroup? We will see, that the induced representation, which will be defined in the following, provides us with the necessary concept. Admittedly, this construction is not inverse but adjoint to the restriction.

===Definitions===
Let <math>\rho: G\to \text{GL}(V_\rho)</math> be a linear representation of <math>G.</math> Let <math>H</math> be a subgroup and <math>\rho|_H</math> the restriction. Let <math>W</math> be a subrepresentation of <math>\rho_H.</math> We write <math>\theta:H \to \text{GL}(W)</math> to denote this representation. Let <math>s\in G.</math> The vector space <math>\rho(s)(W)</math> depends only on  the [[coset|left coset]] <math>sH</math> of <math>s.</math> Let <math>R</math> be a [[Equivalence class#Notation and formal definition|representative system]] of <math>G/H,</math> then 

:<math> \sum_{r\in R} \rho(r)(W)</math> 

is a subrepresentation of <math>V_\rho.</math>

A representation <math>\rho</math> of <math>G</math> in <math>V_\rho</math> is called '''induced''' by the representation <math>\theta</math> of <math>H</math> in <math>W,</math> if 

:<math> V_\rho= \bigoplus_{r\in R} W_r.</math> 

Here <math>R</math> denotes a representative system of <math>G/H</math> and <math>W_r=\rho(s)(W)</math> for all <math>s\in rH</math> and for all <math>r\in R.</math> In other words: the representation <math>(\rho,V_\rho)</math> is induced by <math>(\theta, W),</math> if every <math>v\in V_\rho</math> can be written uniquely as 

:<math>\sum_{r\in R}w_r,</math> 

where <math>w_r \in W_r</math> for every <math>r\in R.</math>

We denote the representation <math>\rho</math> of <math>G</math> which is induced by the representation <math>\theta</math> of <math>H</math> as <math>\rho=\text{Ind}^G_H(\theta),</math> or in short <math>\rho=\text{Ind}(\theta),</math> if there is no danger of confusion. The representation space itself is frequently used instead of the representation map, i.e. <math>V=\text{Ind}^G_H(W),</math> or <math>V=\text{Ind}(W),</math> if the representation <math>V</math> is induced by <math>W.</math>

====Alternative description of the induced representation====
By using the [[#Representations, modules and the convolution algebra|group algebra]] we obtain an alternative description of the induced representation: 

Let <math>G</math> be a group, <math>V</math> a <math>\Complex [G]</math>–module and <math>W</math> a <math>\Complex [H]</math>–submodule of <math>V</math> corresponding to the subgroup <math>H</math> of <math>G.</math> We say, <math>V</math> is induced by <math>W,</math> if <math>V= \Complex[G]\otimes_{\Complex[H]}W,</math> in which <math>G</math> acts on the first factor: <math>s\cdot (e_t \otimes w)=e_{st}\otimes w</math> for all <math>s,t\in G, w\in W.</math>

===Properties===
The results introduced in this section will be presented without proof. These may be found in [[#Literature| '''[1]''']] and [[#Literature| '''[2]''']].

:'''Uniqueness and existence of the induced representation.''' Let <math>(\theta, W_\theta)</math> be a linear representation of a subgroup <math>H</math> of <math>G.</math> Then there exists a linear representation <math>(\rho, V_\rho)</math> of <math>G,</math> which is induced by <math>(\theta, W_\theta).</math> Note that this representation is unique up to isomorphism.

:'''Transitivity of induction.''' Let <math>W</math> be a representation of <math>H</math> and let <math> H \leq G \leq K</math> be an ascending series of groups. Then we have
::<math>\text{Ind}^K_G(\text{Ind}^G_H(W))\cong\text{Ind}^K_H(W).</math>

:'''Lemma.''' Let <math>(\rho, V_\rho)</math> be induced by <math>(\theta,W_\theta)</math> and let <math>\rho':G\to\text{GL}(V')</math> be a linear representation of <math>G.</math> Now let <math>F: W_\theta\to V'</math> be a linear map satisfying the property, that <math>F\circ\theta(t)=\rho'(t)\circ F</math> for all <math>t\in G.</math> Then there exists a uniquely determined linear map <math>F':V_\rho\to V',</math> which extends <math>F</math> and for which <math>F'\circ\rho(s)=\rho'(s)\circ F'</math> is valid for all <math>s\in G.</math>

This means, that if we interpret <math>V'</math> as a <math>\Complex[G]</math>–module, we have: <math>\text{Hom}^H(W_\theta,V') \cong \text{Hom}^G(V_\rho,V'),</math> where <math>\text{Hom}^G(V_\rho,V')</math> is the vector space of all <math>\Complex[G]</math>–homomorphisms of <math>V_\rho</math> to <math>V'.</math> The same is valid for <math>\text{Hom}^H(W_\theta,V').</math>

'''Induction on class functions.''' In the same way as it was done with representations, we can, using the so-called induction, obtain a class function on the group out of a class function on a subgroup. Let <math>\varphi</math> be a class function on <math>H.</math> We define the function <math>\varphi'</math> on <math>G</math> by
:<math> \varphi'(s)=\frac{1}{|H|}\sum_{t\in G\atop t^{-1}st\in H}^{}\varphi(t^{-1}st).</math>
We say <math>\varphi'</math> is induced by <math>\varphi</math> and write <math>\text{Ind}^G_H(\varphi)=\varphi'</math> or <math>\text{Ind}(\varphi)=\varphi'.</math>

:'''Proposition.''' The function <math>\text{Ind}(\varphi)</math> is a class function on <math>G.</math> If <math>\varphi</math> is the [[#Definitions|character]] of a representation <math>W</math> of <math>H,</math> then <math>\text{Ind}(\varphi)</math> is the character of the induced representation <math>\text{Ind}(W)</math> of <math>G.</math>

:'''Lemma.''' If <math>\psi</math> is a class function on <math>H</math> and <math>\varphi</math> is a class function on <math>G,</math> we have: <math> \text{Ind}(\psi \cdot \text{Res}\varphi) = (\text{Ind} \psi) \cdot \varphi.</math>

:'''Theorem.''' Let <math>(\rho,V_\rho)</math> be the representation of <math>G</math> induced by the representation <math>(\theta,W_\theta)</math> of the subgroup <math>H.</math> Let <math>\chi_\rho</math> and <math> \chi_\theta</math> be the corresponding characters. Let <math>R</math> be a representative system of <math>G/H.</math> The induced character is given by
::<math>\forall t \in G: \qquad \chi_\rho(t)=\sum_{r\in R,\atop r^{-1}tr \in H}^{} \chi_\theta (r^{-1}tr)=\frac{1}{|H|} \sum_{s\in G,\atop s^{-1}ts\in H}^{} \chi_\theta(s^{-1}ts).</math>

===Frobenius reciprocity===
{{Main|Frobenius reciprocity}}
The message of the Frobenius reciprocity is, that the maps <math>\text{Res}</math> and <math>\text{Ind}</math> are [[Hermitian adjoint|adjoint]] to each other.

Let <math>W</math> be an irreducible representation of <math>H</math> and let <math>V</math> be an irreducible representation of <math>G,</math> then the Frobenius reciprocity tells us, that <math>W</math> is contained in <math>\text{Res}(V)</math> as often as <math>\text{Ind}(W)</math> is contained in <math>V.</math>

:'''Frobenius reciprocity.''' If <math>\psi\in\Complex _{\text{class}}(H)</math> and <math>\varphi\in\Complex _{\text{class}}(G)</math> we have <math>\langle \psi, \text{Res}(\varphi)\rangle_H=\langle \text{Ind}(\psi), \varphi\rangle_G.</math>

This statement is also valid for the [[#Inner product and characters|inner product]].

===Mackey's irreducibility criterion===
[[George Mackey]] has established a criterion to verify the irreducibility of induced representations. For this we will first need some definitions and some specifications with respect to the notation.

Two representations <math>V_1</math> and <math>V_2</math> of a group <math>G</math> are called '''disjoint''', if they have no irreducible component in common, i.e. if <math>\langle V_1,V_2\rangle_G =0.</math>

Let <math>G</math> be a group and let <math>H</math> be a subgroup. We define <math>H_s=sHs^{-1}\cap H</math> for <math>s \in G.</math> Let <math>(\rho, W)</math> be a representation of the subgroup <math>H.</math> This defines by restriction  a representation <math>\text{Res}_s(\rho)</math> of <math>H_s.</math> We write <math>\text{Res}_s(\rho)</math> for <math>\text{Res}_{H_s}(\rho).</math> We also define another representation <math>\rho^s</math> of <math>H_s</math> by <math>\rho^s(t)=\rho(s^{-1}ts).</math> These two representations are not to be confused.

:'''Mackey's irreducibility criterion.''' The induced representation <math>V=\text{Ind}^G_H(W)</math> is irreducible if and only if the following conditions are satisfied:
:* <math>W</math> is irreducible
:* For each <math>s\in G\setminus H</math> the two representations <math>\rho^s</math> and <math>\text{Res}_s(\rho)</math> of <math>H_s</math> are disjoint.<ref>A proof of this theorem may be found in [[#Literature| '''[1]''']].</ref>

For the case of <math>H</math> normal, we have <math>H_s=H</math> and <math>\text{Res}_s(\rho)=\rho</math>.  Thusly do we obtain the following:

:'''Corollary.''' Let <math>H</math> be a normal subgroup of <math>G.</math> Then <math>\text{Ind}^G_H(\rho)</math> is irreducible if and only if <math>\rho</math> is irreducible and not isomorphic to the conjugates <math>\rho^s</math> for <math>s \notin H.</math>

===Applications to special groups===
In this section we present some applications of the so far presented theory to normal subgroups and to a special group, the semidirect product of a subgroup with an abelian normal subgroup.

:'''Proposition.''' Let <math>A</math> be a [[normal subgroup]] of the group <math>G</math> and let <math>\rho: G\to\text{GL}(V)</math> be an irreducible representation of <math>G.</math> Then one of the following statements has to be valid:
:* either there exists a proper subgroup <math>H</math> of <math>G</math> containing <math>A</math>, and an irreducible representation <math>\eta</math> of <math>H</math> which induces <math>\rho</math>,
:* or <math>V</math> is an isotypic <math>\mathbb{C}A</math>-module.
:'''Proof.''' Consider <math>V</math> as an <math>\mathbb{C}A</math>-module, and decompose it into isotypes as <math>V=\bigoplus_j{V_j}</math>.  If this decomposition is trivial, we are in the second case.  Otherwise, the larger <math>G</math>-action permutes these isotypic modules; because <math>V</math> is irreducible as a <math>\mathbb{C}G</math>-module, the permutation action is [[transitive action|transitive]] (in fact [[primitive action|primitive]]).  Fix any <math>j</math>; the [[Stabilizer subgroup|stabilizer]] in <math>G</math> of <math>V_j</math> is elementarily seen to exhibit the claimed properties.     <math>\Box</math>

Note that if <math>A</math> is abelian, then the isotypic modules of <math>A</math> are irreducible, of degree one, and all homotheties.  

We obtain also the following

:'''Corollary.''' Let <math>A</math> be an abelian normal subgroup of <math>G</math> and let <math>\tau</math> be any irreducible representation of <math>G.</math> We denote with <math>(G : A)</math> the [[Index of a subgroup|index]] of <math>A</math> in <math>G.</math> Then <math>\deg(\tau)|(G : A).</math>[[#Literature|'''[1]''']]

If <math>A</math> is an abelian subgroup of <math>G</math> (not necessarily normal), generally <math>\deg(\tau)|(G : A)</math> is not satisfied, but nevertheless <math>\deg(\tau) \leq (G : A) </math> is still valid.

====Classification of representations of a semidirect product====
In the following, let <math>G=A\rtimes H</math> be a semidirect product such that the normal semidirect factor, <math>A</math>, is abelian.  <!--There is inconsistent notation in the literature as to whether the ''left'' or the ''right'' semidirect factor is normal, so it's better to spell it out.-->  The irreducible representations of such a group <math>G,</math> can be classified by showing that all irreducible representations of <math>G</math> can be constructed from certain subgroups of <math>H</math>. This is the so-called method of “little groups” of Wigner and Mackey.

Since <math>A</math> is [[abelian group|abelian]], the irreducible characters of <math>A</math> have degree one and form the group <math>\Chi = \text{Hom}(A,\Complex^\times).</math> The group <math>G</math> [[Group action (mathematics)|acts]] on <math>\Chi</math> by <math>(s\chi)(a) = \chi(s^{-1}as)</math> for <math>s \in G, \chi \in \Chi, a \in A.</math>

Let <math>(\chi_j)_{j\in \Chi/H}</math> be a [[Equivalence class#Notation and formal definition|representative system]] of the [[Group action (mathematics)#Orbits and stabilizers|orbit]] of <math>H</math> in <math>\Chi.</math> For every <math>j \in \Chi/H</math> let <math>H_j = \{t \in H : t\chi_j = \chi_j\}.</math> This is a subgroup of <math>H.</math> Let <math>G_j = A \cdot H_j</math> be the corresponding subgroup of <math>G.</math> We now extend the function <math>\chi_j</math> onto <math>G_j</math> by <math>\chi_j(at) = \chi_j(a)</math> for <math>a \in A, t \in H_j.</math> Thus, <math>\chi_j</math> is a class function on <math>G_j.</math> Moreover, since <math>t\chi_j = \chi_j</math> for all <math>t \in H_j,</math> it can be shown that <math>\chi_j</math> is a group homomorphism from <math>G_j</math> to <math>\Complex^\times.</math> Therefore, we have a representation of <math>G_j</math> of degree one which is equal to its own character.

Let now <math>\rho</math> be an irreducible representation of <math>H_j. </math> Then we obtain an irreducible representation <math>\tilde{\rho}</math> of <math>G_j,</math> by combining <math>\rho</math> with the [[Projection (linear algebra)|canonical projection]] <math>G_j \to H_j.</math> Finally, we construct the [[#Tensor product of representations|tensor product]] of <math>\chi_j</math> and <math>\tilde{\rho}.</math> Thus, we obtain an irreducible representation <math>\chi_j\otimes \tilde{\rho}</math> of <math>G_j.</math>

To finally obtain the classification of the irreducible representations of <math>G</math> we use the representation <math>\theta_{j,\rho}</math> of <math>G,</math> which is induced by the tensor product <math>\chi_j\otimes \tilde{\rho}.</math> Thus, we achieve the following result:

:'''Proposition.'''
:* <math>\theta_{j,\rho}</math> is irreducible.
:* If <math>\theta_{j,\rho}</math> and <math>\theta_{j',\rho'}</math> are isomorphic, then <math>j = j'</math> and additionally <math>\rho</math> is isomorphic to <math>\rho'.</math>
:* Every irreducible representation of <math>G</math> is isomorphic to one of the <math>\theta_{j,\rho}.</math>

Amongst others, the criterion of Mackey and a conclusion based on the Frobenius reciprocity are needed for the proof of the proposition. Further details may be found in [[#Literature|'''[1]''']].

In other words we classified all irreducible representations of <math>G=A \rtimes H.</math>

==Representation ring==
The representation ring of <math>G</math> is defined as the abelian group
:<math>R(G)= \left \{ \left. \sum_{j=1}^m a_j \tau_j \right |\tau_1, \ldots, \tau_m \text{ all irreducible representations of } G \text{ up to isomorphism},  a_j\in\Z \right \}.</math>
With the multiplication provided by the [[#Tensor product of representations|tensor product]], <math>R(G)</math> becomes a ring. The elements of <math>R(G)</math> are called '''virtual representations'''.

The character defines a [[ring homomorphism]] in the set of all class functions on <math>G</math> with complex values

:<math> \begin{cases} \chi: R(G)\to\Complex _{\text{class}}(G)\\ \sum a_j \tau_j \mapsto \sum a_j \chi_j \end{cases} </math>

in which the <math>\chi_j</math> are the irreducible characters corresponding to the <math>\tau_j.</math>

Because a representation is determined by its character, <math>\chi</math> is [[Injective function|injective]]. The images of <math>\chi</math> are called '''virtual characters'''.

As the irreducible characters form an [[orthonormal basis]] of <math>\Complex _{\text{class}}, \chi</math> induces an isomorphism
:<math>\chi_\Complex : R(G)\otimes\Complex  \to \Complex _{\text{class}}(G). </math>
This isomorphism is defined on a basis out of [[Tensor product#Relation to dual space|elementary tensors]] <math>(\tau_j\otimes1)_{j=1,\ldots, m}</math> by <math>\chi_{\Complex }(\tau_j\otimes1)=\chi_j</math> respectively <math>\chi_{\Complex }(\tau_j\otimes z)=z\chi_j,</math> and extended [[bilinear map|bilinearly]].

We write <math>\mathcal{R}^+(G)</math> for the set of all characters of <math>G</math> and <math>\mathcal{R}(G)</math> to denote the group generated by <math>\mathcal{R}^+(G),</math> i.e. the set of all differences of two characters. It holds  <math>\mathcal{R}(G)=\Z \chi_1\oplus \cdots \oplus\Z \chi_m</math> and <math>\mathcal{R}(G)=\text{Im}(\chi)=\chi(R(G)).</math> Thus, we have <math>R(G)\cong\mathcal{R}(G)</math> and the virtual characters correspond to the virtual representations in an optimal manner.

Since <math>\mathcal{R}(G)=\text{Im}(\chi)</math> holds, <math>\mathcal{R}(G)</math> is the set of all virtual characters. As the product of two characters provides another character, <math>\mathcal{R}(G)</math> is a subring of the ring <math>\Complex_{\text{class}}(G)</math> of all class functions on <math>G.</math> Because the <math>\chi_i</math> form a basis of <math>\Complex _{\text{class}}(G)</math> we obtain, just as in the case of <math>R(G),</math> an isomorphism <math>\Complex \otimes \mathcal{R}(G)\cong\Complex _{\text{class}}(G).</math>

Let <math>H</math> be a subgroup of <math>G.</math> The restriction thus defines a ring homomorphism <math>\mathcal{R}(G)\to \mathcal{R}(H), \phi\mapsto \phi|_H,</math> which will be denoted by <math>\text{Res}^G_H</math> or <math>\text{Res}.</math> Likewise, the induction on class functions defines a homomorphism of abelian groups <math>\mathcal{R}(H)\to \mathcal{R}(G),</math> which will be written as <math>\text{Ind}^G_H</math> or in short <math>\text{Ind}.</math>

According to the [[#Frobenius reciprocity|Frobenius reciprocity]], these two homomorphisms are adjoint with respect to the bilinear forms <math>\langle \cdot,\cdot\rangle_H</math> and <math>\langle \cdot,\cdot\rangle_G.</math> Furthermore, the formula <math>\text{Ind}(\varphi\cdot \text{Res}(\psi))=\text{Ind}(\varphi)\cdot \psi</math> shows that the image of <math>\text{Ind}:\mathcal{R}(H)\to \mathcal{R}(G)</math> is an [[Ideal (ring theory)|ideal]] of the ring <math>\mathcal{R}(G).</math>

By the restriction of representations, the map <math>\text{Res}</math> can be defined analogously for <math>R(G),</math> and by the induction we obtain the map <math>\text{Ind}</math> for <math>R(G).</math> Due to the Frobenius reciprocity, we get the result, that these maps are adjoint to each other and that the image <math>\text{Im}(\text{Ind})=\text{Ind}(R(H))</math> is an [[Ideal (ring theory)|ideal]] of the ring <math>R(G).</math>

If <math>A</math> is a commutative ring, the homomorphisms <math>\text{Res}</math> and <math>\text{Ind}</math> may be extended to <math>A</math>–linear maps:
:<math> \begin{cases}
A\otimes \text{Res}: A\otimes R(G) \to A\otimes R(H)\\
\left (a \otimes \sum a_j \tau_j \right ) \mapsto \left (a \otimes \sum a_j \text{Res}(\tau_j) \right )
\end{cases}, \qquad  \begin{cases}
 A\otimes \text{Ind}: A\otimes R(H) \to A\otimes R(G)\\
\left (a \otimes \sum a_j \eta_j \right )\mapsto \left (a \otimes \sum a_j \text{Ind}(\eta_j) \right )
\end{cases}</math>

in which <math>\eta_j</math> are all the irreducible representations of <math>H</math> up to isomorphism.

With <math>A=\Complex </math> we obtain in particular, that <math>\text{Ind}</math> and <math>\text{Res}</math> supply homomorphisms between <math>\Complex _{\text{class}}(G)</math> and <math>\Complex _{\text{class}}(H).</math>

Let <math>G_1</math> and <math>G_2</math> be two groups with respective representations <math>(\rho_1, V_1)</math> and <math>(\rho_2, V_2).</math> Then, <math>\rho_1\otimes\rho_2</math> is the representation of the [[direct product]] <math>G_1\times G_2</math> as was shown in a [[#Tensor product of representations|previous section]]. Another result of that section was, that all irreducible representations of <math>G_1\times G_2</math> are exactly the representations <math>\eta_1\otimes\eta_2,</math> where <math>\eta_1</math> and <math>\eta_2</math> are irreducible representations of <math>G_1</math> and <math>G_2,</math> respectively. This passes over to the representation ring as the identity <math>R(G_1\times G_2)=R(G_1)\otimes_{\Z} R(G_2),</math> in which <math>R(G_1)\otimes_{\Z} R(G_2)</math> is the [[tensor product of modules|tensor product]] of the representation rings as <math>\Z</math>–modules.
==Induction theorems==

Induction theorems relate the representation ring of a given finite group ''G'' to representation rings of a family ''X'' consisting of some subsets ''H'' of ''G''. More precisely, for such a collection of subgroups, the induction functor yields a map 
:<math>\varphi: \text{Ind}:\bigoplus_{H\in X}\mathcal{R}(H) \to \mathcal{R}(G)</math>; induction theorems give criteria for the surjectivity of this map or closely related ones.
''Artin's induction theorem'' is the most elementary theorem in this group of results. It asserts that the following are equivalent:

* The [[cokernel]] of <math>\varphi</math> is finite.

* <math>G</math> is the union of the conjugates of the subgroups belonging to <math>X,</math> i.e. <math>G=\bigcup_{H\in X \atop s\in G}sHs^{-1}.</math>

Since <math>\mathcal{R}(G)</math> is finitely generated as a group, the first point can be rephrased as follows:
*For each character <math>\chi</math> of <math>G,</math> there exist virtual characters <math>\chi_H \in \mathcal{R}(H), \,H\in X</math> and an integer <math> d\geq 1,</math> such that <math> d\cdot\chi = \sum_{H\in X}\text{Ind}^G_H(\chi_H).</math>
{{harvtxt|Serre|1977}} gives two proofs of this theorem. For example, since ''G'' is the union of its cyclic subgroups, every character of <math>G</math> is a linear combination with rational coefficients of characters induced by characters of [[cyclic group|cyclic subgroups]] of <math>G.</math> Since the representations of cyclic groups are well-understood, in particular the irreducible representations are one-dimensional, this gives a certain control over representations of ''G''.

Under the above circumstances, it is not in general true that <math>\varphi</math> is surjective. ''[[Brauer's theorem on induced characters|Brauer's induction theorem]]'' asserts that <math>\varphi</math> is surjective, provided that ''X'' is the family of all ''elementary subgroups''.
Here a group ''H'' is [[elementary group|elementary]] if there is some prime ''p'' such that ''H'' is the [[direct product]] of a [[cyclic group]] of order prime to <math>p</math> and a [[P-group|<math>p</math>–group]].
In other words, every [[#Character theory|character]] of <math>G</math> is a linear combination with integer coefficients of characters induced by characters of elementary subgroups.
The elementary subgroups ''H'' arising in Brauer's theorem have a richer representation theory than cyclic groups, they at least have the property that any irreducible representation for such ''H'' is induced by a one-dimensional representation of a (necessarily also elementary) subgroup <math>K \subset H</math>. (This latter property can be shown to hold for any [[supersolvable group]], which includes [[nilpotent group]]s and, in particular, elementary groups.) This ability to induce representations from degree 1 representations has some further consequences in the representation theory of finite groups.

==Real representations==
For proofs and more information about representations over general subfields of <math>\Complex </math> please refer to [[#Literature| '''[2]''']].

If a group <math>G</math> acts on a real vector space <math>V_0,</math> the corresponding representation on the complex vector space <math>V=V_0\otimes_\R \Complex </math> is called '''real''' (<math>V</math> is called the [[complexification]] of <math>V_0</math>). The corresponding representation mentioned above is given by <math>s \cdot(v_0\otimes z) = (s\cdot v_0)\otimes z</math> for all <math>s\in G, v_0\in V_0, z\in \Complex.</math>

Let <math>\rho</math> be a real representation. The linear map <math>\rho(s)</math> is <math>\R</math>-valued for all <math>s\in G.</math> Thus, we can conclude, that the character of a real representation is always real-valued. But not every representation with a real-valued character is real. To make this clear, let <math>G</math> be a finite, non-abelian subgroup of the group

:<math>\text{SU}(2)= \left \{\begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ -\overline{b} & \overline{a} \end{pmatrix} \ : \ |a|^2+|b|^2=1 \right \}.</math>

Then <math>G \subset \text{SU}(2)</math> acts on <math>V=\Complex^2.</math> Since the trace of any matrix in <math>\text{SU}(2)</math> is real, the character of the representation is real-valued. Suppose <math>\rho</math> is a real representation, then <math>\rho(G)</math> would consist only of real-valued matrices. Thus, <math>G \subset \text{SU}(2)\cap\text{GL}_2(\R )=\text{SO}(2)=S^1.</math> However the circle group is abelian but <math>G</math> was chosen to be a non-abelian group. Now we only need to prove the existence of a non-abelian, finite subgroup of <math>\text{SU}(2).</math> To find such a group, observe that <math>\text{SU}(2)</math> can be identified with the units of the [[quaternion]]s. Now let <math>G=\{\pm1,\pm i,\pm j, \pm ij \}.</math> The following two-dimensional representation of <math>G</math> is not real-valued, but has a real-valued character:
:<math> \begin{cases} \rho : G \to \text{GL}_2(\Complex ) \\[4pt] \rho(\pm 1)=\begin{pmatrix} \pm1&0\\0& \pm1\end{pmatrix}, \quad \rho(\pm i)=\begin{pmatrix} \pm i&0\\0&\mp i\end{pmatrix}, \quad \rho(\pm j)=\begin{pmatrix} 0&\pm i\\ \pm i&0\end{pmatrix} \end{cases}</math>
Then the image of <math>\rho</math> is not real-valued, but nevertheless it is a subset of <math>\text{SU}(2).</math> Thus, the character of the representation is real.

:'''Lemma.''' An irreducible representation <math>V</math> of <math>G</math> is real if and only if there exists a [[Degenerate bilinear form#Non-degenerate forms|nondegenerate]] [[symmetric bilinear form]] <math>B</math> on <math>V</math> preserved by <math>G.</math>

An irreducible representation of <math>G</math> on a real vector space can become reducible when extending the field to <math>\Complex.</math> For example the following real representation of the cyclic group is reducible when considered over <math>\Complex</math>
:<math>  \begin{cases} \rho : \Z /m\Z  \to \text{GL}_2(\R ) \\[4pt]  \rho(k)= \begin{pmatrix} \cos  \left(\frac{2\pi ik}{m}\right ) & \sin \left (\frac{2\pi ik}{m} \right ) \\ -\sin \left(\frac{2\pi ik}{m} \right ) & \cos \left (\frac{2\pi ik}{m} \right )\end{pmatrix} \end{cases}</math>
 
Therefore by classifying all the irreducible representations that are real over <math>\Complex,</math> we still haven't classified all the irreducible real representations. But we achieve the following:

Let <math>V_0</math> be a real vector space. Let <math>G</math> act irreducibly on <math>V_0</math> and let <math>V=V_0\otimes \Complex.</math> If <math>V</math> is not irreducible, there are exactly two irreducible factors which are complex conjugate representations of <math>G.</math>

'''Definition.''' A '''quaternionic''' representation is a (complex) representation <math>V,</math> which possesses a <math>G</math>–invariant anti-linear homomorphism <math>J:V\to V</math> satisfying <math>J^2=-\text{Id}.</math> Thus, a [[bilinear form#Symmetric, skew-symmetric and alternating forms|skew-symmetric]], nondegenerate <math>G</math>–invariant bilinear form defines a quaternionic structure on <math>V.</math>

:'''Theorem.''' An irreducible representation <math>V</math> is one and only one of the following:
:: (i) complex: <math>\chi_V</math> is not real-valued and there exists no <math>G</math>–invariant [[Degenerate bilinear form#Non-degenerate forms|nondegenerate]] bilinear form on <math>V.</math>
:: (ii) real: <math>V=V_0\otimes \Complex ,</math> a real representation; <math>V</math> has a <math>G</math>–invariant nondegenerate [[symmetric bilinear form]].
:: (iii) quaternionic: <math>\chi_V</math> is real, but <math>V</math> is not real; <math>V</math> has a <math>G</math>–invariant skew-symmetric nondegenerate bilinear form.

==Representations of particular groups==
===Symmetric groups===

{{main|Representation theory of the symmetric group}}
Representation of the [[symmetric group]]s <math>S_n</math> have been intensely studied. Conjugacy classes in <math>S_n</math> (and therefore, by the above, irreducible representations) correspond to [[partition (number theory)|partition]]s of ''n''. For example, <math>S_3</math> has three irreducible representations, corresponding to the partitions

:3; 2+1; 1+1+1

of 3. For such a partition, a [[Young tableau]] is a graphical device depicting a partition. The irreducible representation corresponding to such a partition (or Young tableau) is called a [[Specht module]].

Representations of different symmetric groups are related: any representation of <math>S_n \times S_m</math> yields a representation of <math>S_{n+m}</math> by induction, and vice versa by restriction. The direct sum of all these representation rings

:<math>\bigoplus_{n \ge 0} R(S_n)</math>

inherits from these constructions the structure of a [[Hopf algebra]] which, it turns out, is closely related to [[symmetric function]]s.

===Finite groups of Lie type===

To a certain extent, the representations of the <math>GL_n(\mathbf F_q)</math> , as ''n'' varies, have a similar flavor as for the <math>S_n</math>; the above-mentioned induction process gets replaced by so-called [[parabolic induction]]. However, unlike for <math>S_n</math>, where all representations can be obtained by induction of trivial representations, this is not true for <math>GL_n(\mathbf F_q)</math>. Instead, new building blocks, known as [[cuspidal representation]]s, are needed.

Representations of <math>GL_n(\mathbf F_q)</math> and more generally, representations of [[finite groups of Lie type]] have been thoroughly studied. {{harvtxt|Bonnafé|2011}} describes the representations of <math>SL_2(\mathbf F_q)</math>. A geometric description of irreducible representations of such groups, including the above-mentioned cuspidal representations, is obtained by [[Deligne-Lusztig theory]], which constructs such representation in the [[l-adic cohomology]] of [[Deligne-Lusztig variety|Deligne-Lusztig varieties]].

The similarity of the representation theory of <math>S_n</math> and <math>GL_n(\mathbf F_q)</math> goes beyond finite groups. The [[philosophy of cusp forms]] highlights the kinship of representation theoretic aspects of these types of groups with general linear groups of [[local field]]s such as [[p-adic numbers|'''Q'''<sub>''p''</sub>]] and of the ring of [[adelic algebraic group|adele]]s, see {{harvtxt|Bump|2004}}.

==Outlook—Representations of compact groups==
The theory of representations of compact groups may be, to some degree, extended to [[locally compact group]]s. The representation theory unfolds in this context great importance for harmonic analysis and the study of automorphic forms. For proofs, further information and for a more detailed insight which is beyond the scope of this chapter please consult [[#Literature| '''[4]''']] and [[#Literature| '''[5]''']].

===Definition and properties===
A '''topological group''' is a group together with a [[topology]] with respect to which the group composition and the inversion are [[continuous function|continuous]].
Such a group is called '''compact''', if any cover of <math>G,</math> which is open in the topology, has a finite subcover. Closed subgroups of a compact group are compact again.

Let <math>G</math> be a compact group and let <math>V</math> be a finite-dimensional <math>\Complex</math>–vector space. A linear representation of <math>G</math> to <math>V</math> is a '''continuous group homomorphism''' <math>\rho: G \to \text{GL}(V),</math> i.e. <math>\rho(s)v</math> is a continuous function in the two variables <math>s\in G</math> and <math>v\in V.</math>

A linear representation of <math>G</math> into a [[Banach space]] <math>V</math> is defined to be a continuous group homomorphism of <math>G</math> into the set of all bijective [[bounded operator|bounded linear operators]] on <math>V</math> with a continuous inverse. Since <math>\pi(g)^{-1}=\pi(g^{-1}),</math> we can do without the last requirement. In the following, we will consider in particular representations of compact groups in [[Hilbert space]]s.

Just as with finite groups, we can define the [[#Representations, modules and the convolution algebra|group algebra]] and the [[#Representations, modules and the convolution algebra|convolution algebra]]. However, the group algebra provides no helpful information in the case of infinite groups, because the continuity condition gets lost during the construction. Instead the convolution algebra <math>L^1(G)</math> takes its place.

Most properties of representations of finite groups can be transferred with appropriate changes to compact groups. For this we need a counterpart to the summation over a finite group:

===Existence and uniqueness of the Haar measure=== 
On a compact group <math>G</math> there exists exactly one [[measure (mathematics)|measure]] <math>dt,</math> such that:
* It is a left-translation-invariant measure
::<math>\forall s \in G: \quad \int_{G} f(t) dt = \int_{G} f(st)dt.</math>
* The whole group has unit measure:
::<math>\int_{G} dt=1,</math>
Such a left-translation-invariant, normed measure is called '''[[Haar measure]]''' of the group <math>G.</math>

Since <math>G</math> is compact, it is possible to show that this measure is also right-translation-invariant, i.e. it also applies

:<math>\forall s \in G: \quad  \int_{G} f(t) dt = \int_{G} f(ts)dt.</math>

By the scaling above the Haar measure on a finite group is given by <math>dt(s)=\tfrac{1}{|G|}</math> for all <math>s\in G.</math>

All the definitions to representations of finite groups, that are mentioned in the section [[#Properties|”Properties”]], also apply to representations of compact groups. But there are some modifications needed:

To define a subrepresentation we now need a closed subspace. This was not necessary for finite-dimensional representation spaces, because in this case every subspace is already closed. Furthermore, two representations <math>\rho, \pi</math> of a compact group <math>G</math> are called equivalent, if there exists a bijective, continuous, linear operator <math>T</math> between the representation spaces whose inverse is also continuous and which satisfies <math>T\circ\rho(s)=\pi(s)\circ T</math> for all <math>s\in G.</math>

If <math>T</math> is unitary, the two representations are called '''unitary equivalent'''.

To obtain a <math>G</math>–invariant [[inner product]] from a not <math>G</math>–invariant, we now have to use the integral over <math>G</math> instead of the sum. If <math>(\cdot|\cdot)</math> is an inner product on a [[Hilbert space]] <math>V,</math> which is not invariant with respect to the representation <math>\rho</math> of <math>G,</math> then

:<math> (v|u)_\rho=\int_G(\rho(t)v|\rho(t)u)dt</math>

is a <math>G</math>–invariant inner product on <math>V</math> due to the properties of the Haar measure <math>dt.</math> Thus, we can assume every representation on a Hilbert space to be unitary.

Let <math>G</math> be a compact group and let <math>s\in G.</math> Let <math>L^2(G)</math> be the Hilbert space of the square integrable functions on <math>G.</math> We define the operator <math>L_s</math> on this space by <math>L_s\Phi(t)=\Phi(s^{-1}t),</math> where <math>\Phi\in L^2(G), t\in G.</math>

The map <math>s\mapsto L_s</math> is a unitary representation of <math>G.</math> It is called '''left-regular representation'''. The '''right-regular representation''' is defined similarly. As the Haar measure of <math>G</math> is also right-translation-invariant, the operator <math>R_s</math> on <math>L^2(G)</math> is given by <math>R_s\Phi(t)=\Phi(ts).</math> The right-regular representation is then the unitary representation given by  <math> s\mapsto R_s.</math> The two representations <math>s\mapsto L_s</math> and <math>s\mapsto R_s</math> are dual to each other.

If <math>G</math> is infinite, these representations have no finite degree. The [[#Left- and right-regular representation|left- and right-regular representation]] as defined at the beginning are isomorphic to the left- and right-regular representation as defined above, if the group <math>G</math> is finite. This is due to the fact, that in this case <math>L^2(G)\cong L^1(G)\cong\Complex [G].</math>

===Constructions and decompositions===
The different ways of constructing new representations from given ones can be used for compact groups as well, except for the dual representation with which we will deal later. The [[#Direct sum of representations|direct sum]] and the [[#Tensor product of representations|tensor product]] with a finite number of summands/factors are defined in exactly the same way as for finite groups. This is also the case for the symmetric and alternating square. Additionally, we need a Haar measure on the [[direct product]] of groups in order to obtain also for compact groups the result, that the irreducible representations of the product of two groups are, up to isomorphism, exactly the tensor product of the irreducible representations of the single groups. The direct product of two compact groups <math>G_1\times G_2</math> is again a compact group, if provided with the product topology. The Haar measure on this group is given by the product of the Haar measures of the single groups.

For the dual representation on compact groups we require the [[Dual space#Continuous dual space|topological dual]] <math>V'</math> of the vector space <math>V.</math> This is the vector space of all continuous linear functionals from the vector space <math>V</math> into the base field. Let <math>\pi</math> be a representation of a compact group <math>G</math> in <math>V.</math>

The dual representation <math>\pi':G\to\text{GL}(V')</math> is defined by the property 

:<math>\forall v\in V, \forall v'\in V', \forall s\in G: \qquad  \left \langle\pi'(s)v',\pi(s)v \right \rangle=\langle v',v\rangle := v'(v).</math> 

Thus, we can conclude, that the dual representation is given by <math>\pi'(s)v'=v'\circ\pi(s^{-1})</math> for all <math>v'\in V', s\in G.</math> The map <math>\pi'</math> is again a continuous group homomorphism and thus a representation.

On Hilbert spaces: <math>\pi</math> is irreducible if and only if <math>\pi'</math> is irreducible.

By transferring the results of the section [[#Decompositions|decompositions]] to compact groups, we obtain the following theorems:

:'''Theorem.''' Every irreducible representation <math>(\tau,V_\tau)</math> of a compact group into a [[Hilbert space]] is finite-dimensional and there exists an [[inner product]] on <math>V_\tau</math> such that <math>\tau</math> is unitary. Since the Haar measure is normalized, this inner product is unique.

Every representation of a compact group is isomorphic to a [[Direct sum of modules#Direct sum of Hilbert spaces|direct Hilbert sum]] of irreducible representations.

Let <math>(\rho,V_\rho)</math> be a unitary representation of the compact group <math>G.</math> Just as for finite groups we define for an irreducible representation <math>(\tau, V_\tau)</math> the isotype or isotypic component in <math>\rho</math> to be the subspace 

:<math>V_\rho(\tau)=\sum_{V_{\tau} \cong U\subset V_\rho} U.</math>

This is the sum of all invariant closed subspaces <math>U,</math> which are <math>G</math>–isomorphic to <math>V_\tau.</math>

Note, that the isotypes of not equivalent irreducible representations are pairwise orthogonal.

:'''Theorem.'''
::(i) <math>V_\rho(\tau)</math> is a closed invariant subspace of <math>V_\rho.</math>
::(ii) <math>V_\rho(\tau)</math> is <math>G</math>–isomorphic to the direct sum of copies of <math>V_\tau.</math>
::(iii) Canonical decomposition: <math> V_\rho</math> is the direct Hilbert sum of the isotypes <math>V_\rho(\tau),</math> in which <math>\tau</math> passes through all the isomorphism classes of the irreducible representations.

The corresponding projection to the canonical decomposition <math>p_\tau: V\to V(\tau),</math> in which <math>V(\tau)</math> is an isotype of <math>V,</math> is for compact groups given by
:<math>p_\tau(v)=n_\tau\int_G\overline{\chi_\tau(t)}\rho(t)(v)dt,</math>
where <math>n_\tau=\dim (V(\tau))</math> and <math>\chi_\tau</math> is the character corresponding to the irreducible representation <math>\tau.</math>

====Projection formula==== 
For every representation <math>(\rho,V)</math> of a compact group <math>G</math> we define 

:<math>V^G=\{v\in V : \rho(s)v=v \,\,\,\forall s \in G\}.</math>

In general <math>\rho(s): V\to V</math> is not <math>G</math>–linear. Let 

: <math> Pv:= \int_G \rho(s)vds. </math>

The map <math>P</math> is defined as [[endomorphism]] on <math>V</math> by having the property

:<math> \left. \left  (\int_G \rho(s)v ds \right |w \right )=\int_G (\rho(s)v|w) ds,</math>

which is valid for the inner product of the Hilbert space <math>V.</math>

Then <math>P</math> is <math>G</math>–linear, because of
:<math> \begin{align}
\left. \left  (\int_G \rho(s)(\rho(t)v) ds \right |w \right )&=\int_G \left. \left  (\rho \left (tst^{-1} \right )(\rho(t)v) \right |w \right ) ds \\
&= \int_G  (\rho(ts)v|w) ds \\
&= \int(\rho(t)\rho(s)v|w) ds \\
&= \left. \left  (\rho(t)\int_G \rho(s)v ds \right |w \right ),
\end{align} </math>
where we used the invariance of the Haar measure.

:'''Proposition.''' The map <math>P</math> is a projection from <math>V</math> to <math>V^G.</math>

If the representation is finite-dimensional, it is possible to determine the direct sum of the trivial subrepresentation just as in the case of finite groups.

===Characters, Schur's lemma and the inner product===
Generally, representations of compact groups are investigated on [[Hilbert space|Hilbert-]] and [[Banach space]]s. In most cases they are not finite-dimensional. Therefore, it is not useful to refer to [[#Character theory|characters]] when speaking about representations of compact groups. Nevertheless in most cases it is possible to restrict the study to the case of finite dimensions:

Since irreducible representations of compact groups are finite-dimensional and unitary (see results from the [[#Definition and properties|first subsection]]), we can define irreducible characters in the same way as it was done for finite groups.

As long as the constructed representations stay finite-dimensional, the characters of the newly constructed representations may be obtained in the same way as for finite groups.

'''Schur's lemma''' is also valid for compact groups:

Let <math>(\pi,V)</math> be an irreducible unitary representation of a compact group <math>G.</math> Then every bounded [[Operator (mathematics)#linear operators|operator]] <math>T:V\to V</math> satisfying the property <math>T\circ\pi(s)=\pi(s)\circ T</math> for all <math>s\in G,</math> is a scalar multiple of the identity, i.e. there exists <math>\lambda \in \Complex </math> such that <math>T=\lambda \text{Id}.</math>

'''Definition.''' The formula
:<math> (\Phi|\Psi)=\int_G\Phi(t)\overline{\Psi(t)}dt.</math>
defines an inner product on the set of all square integrable functions <math>L^2(G)</math> of a compact group <math>G.</math> Likewise 
:<math>\langle\Phi,\Psi\rangle=\int_G\Phi(t)\Psi(t^{-1})dt.</math>
defines a bilinear form on <math>L^2(G)</math> of a compact group <math>G.</math>

The bilinear form on the representation spaces is defined exactly as it was for finite groups and analogous to finite groups the following results are therefore valid:

:'''Theorem.''' Let <math>\chi</math> and <math>\chi'</math> be the characters of two non-isomorphic irreducible representations <math>V</math> and <math>V',</math> respectively. Then the following is valid 
:*<math>(\chi|\chi')=0.</math>
:*<math>(\chi|\chi)=1,</math> i.e. <math>\chi</math> has "norm" <math>1.</math>

:'''Theorem.''' Let <math>V</math> be a representation of <math>G</math> with character <math>\chi_V.</math> Suppose <math>W</math> is an irreducible representation of <math>G</math> with character <math>\chi_W.</math> The number of subrepresentations of <math>V</math> equivalent to <math>W</math> is independent of any given decomposition for <math>V</math> and is equal to the inner product <math>(\chi_V|\chi_W).</math>

:'''Irreducibility Criterion.''' Let <math>\chi</math> be the character of the representation <math>V,</math> then <math>(\chi|\chi)</math> is a positive integer. Moreover <math>(\chi|\chi)=1</math> if and only if <math>V</math> is irreducible.

Therefore, using the first theorem, the characters of irreducible representations of <math>G</math> form an [[Orthonormality|orthonormal set]] on <math>L^2(G)</math> with respect to this inner product.

:'''Corollary.''' Every irreducible representation <math>V</math> of <math>G</math> is contained <math>\dim (V)</math>–times in the left-regular representation.

:'''Lemma.''' Let <math>G</math> be a compact group. Then the following statements are equivalent:
:* <math>G</math> is abelian.
:* All the irreducible representations of <math>G</math> have degree <math>1.</math>

:'''Orthonormal Property.''' Let <math>G</math> be a group. The non-isomorphic irreducible representations of <math>G</math> form an [[orthonormal basis]] in <math>L^2(G)</math> with respect to this inner product.

As we already know, that the non-isomorphic irreducible representations are orthonormal, we only need to verify, that they generate <math>L^2(G).</math> This may be done, by proving, that there exists no non-zero square integrable function on <math>G</math> orthogonal to all the irreducible characters.

Just as in the case of finite groups, the number of the irreducible representations up to isomorphism of a group <math>G</math> equals the number of conjugacy classes of <math>G.</math> However, because a compact group has in general infinitely many conjugacy classes, this does not provide any useful information.

===The induced representation===
If <math>H</math> is a closed subgroup of finite [[Index of a subgroup|index]] in the compact group <math>G,</math> the definition of the [[#The induced representation|induced representation]] for finite groups may be adopted.

However, the induced representation can be defined more generally, so that the definition is valid independent of the index of the subgroup <math>H.</math>

For this purpose let <math>(\eta, V_\eta)</math> be a unitary representation of the closed subgroup <math>H.</math> The continuous induced representation <math>\text{Ind}^G_H(\eta)=(I,V_I)</math> is defined as follows:

Let <math>V_I</math> denote the Hilbert space of all measurable, square integrable functions <math>\Phi:G\to V_\eta</math> with the property <math>\Phi(ls)=\eta(l)\Phi(s)</math> for all <math>l\in H, s\in G.</math> The norm is given by

:<math>\|\Phi\|_G=\text{sup}_{s\in G}\|\Phi(s)\|</math>

and the representation <math>I</math> is given as the right-translation: <math>I(s)\Phi(k)=\Phi(ks).</math>

The induced representation is then again a unitary representation.

Since <math>G</math> is compact, the induced representation can be decomposed into the direct sum of irreducible representations of <math>G.</math> Note, that all irreducible representations belonging to the same isotype appear with a multiplicity equal to <math>\dim (\text{Hom}_G(V_\eta,V_I))=\langle V_\eta,V_I \rangle_G.</math>

Let <math>(\rho, V_\rho)</math> be a representation of <math>G,</math> then there exists a canonical isomorphism
:<math>T: \text{Hom}_G(V_\rho, I^G_H(\eta))\to \text{Hom}_H(V_\rho|_H, V_\eta).</math>

The [[#Frobenius reciprocity|Frobenius reciprocity]] transfers, together with the modified definitions of the inner product and of the bilinear form, to compact groups. The theorem now holds for square integrable functions on <math>G</math> instead of class functions and the subgroup <math>H</math> must be closed.

===Theorem of Peter-Weyl===
{{further information|Peter-Weyl theorem}}
Another important result in the representation theory of compact groups is the Theorem of Peter-Weyl. It is usually presented and proved in the [[harmonic analysis]], as it represents one of its central and fundamental statements.

:'''Theorem of Peter-Weyl.''' Let <math>G</math> be a compact group. For every irreducible representation <math>(\tau, V_\tau)</math> of <math>G</math> let <math>\{e_1,\ldots,e_{\dim (\tau)}\}</math> be an [[orthonormal basis]] of <math>V_\tau.</math> We define the matrix coefficients <math>\tau_{k,l}(s)=\langle\tau(s)e_k,e_l\rangle</math> for <math>k,l \in \{1, \ldots, \dim (\tau)\}, s\in G.</math> Then we have the following [[orthonormal basis]] of <math>L^2(G)</math>:
::<math>\left (\sqrt{\dim (\tau)}\tau_{k,l} \right)_{k,l}</math>

We can reformulate this theorem to obtain a generalization of the Fourier series for functions on compact groups:

:'''Theorem of Peter-Weyl (Second version).'''<ref>A proof of this theorem and more information regarding the representation theory of compact groups may be found in [[#Literature| '''[5]''']].</ref> There exists a natural <math>G\times G</math>–isomorphism 
::<math> L^2(G)\cong_{G\times G} \widehat{\bigoplus}_{\tau \in \widehat{G}}\text{End}(V_\tau)\cong_{G\times G} \widehat{\bigoplus}_{\tau \in \widehat{G}} \tau\otimes\tau^* </math>
:in which <math>\widehat{G}</math> is the set of all irreducible representations of <math>G</math> up to isomorphism and <math>V_\tau</math> is the representation space corresponding to <math>\tau.</math> More concretely:
::<math>\begin{cases}\Phi \mapsto \sum_{\tau\in \widehat{G}}\tau(\Phi) \\[5pt] \tau(\Phi)=\int_G \Phi(t)\tau(t)dt\in \text{End}(V_\tau) \end{cases} </math>

==History==
The general features of the [[group representation|representation theory]] of a [[finite group]] ''G'', over the [[complex number]]s, were discovered by [[Ferdinand Georg Frobenius]] in the years before 1900. Later the [[modular representation theory]] of [[Richard Brauer]] was developed.

pages.title: Modular representation theory
pages.text:
'''Modular representation theory''' is a branch of [[mathematics]], and that part of [[representation theory]] that studies [[linear representation]]s of [[finite group]]s over a [[field (mathematics)|field]] ''K'' of positive [[characteristic (algebra)|characteristic]] ''p'', necessarily a prime number. As well as having applications to group theory, modular representations arise naturally in other branches of mathematics, such as [[algebraic geometry]], [[coding theory]]{{Citation needed|reason=unveriviable and unsufficient citation about the source|date=May 2017}}, [[combinatorics]] and [[number theory]].

Within finite [[group theory]], character-theoretic results proved by [[Richard Brauer]] using modular representation theory played an important role in early progress towards the [[classification of finite simple groups]], especially for simple groups whose characterization was not amenable to purely group-theoretic methods because their Sylow 2 subgroups were too small in an appropriate sense. Also, a general result on embedding of elements of order 2 in finite groups called the [[Z* theorem]], proved by [[George Glauberman]] using the theory developed by Brauer, was particularly useful in the classification program.

If the characteristic ''p'' of ''K'' does not divide the order |''G''|, then modular representations are completely reducible, as with ''ordinary'' (characteristic 0) representations, by virtue of  [[Maschke's theorem]]. In the other case, when |''G''| ≡ 0 mod ''p'', the process of averaging over the group needed to prove Maschke's theorem breaks down, and representations need not be completely reducible. Much of the discussion below implicitly assumes that the field ''K'' is sufficiently large (for example, ''K'' algebraically closed suffices), otherwise some statements need refinement.

==History==

The earliest work on representation theory over finite fields is by {{harvtxt|Dickson|1902}} who showed that when ''p'' does not divide the order of the group, the representation theory is similar to that in characteristic 0. He also investigated [[modular invariant of a group|modular invariants]] of some finite groups. The systematic study of modular representations, when the characteristic ''p'' divides the order of the group,  was started by {{harvtxt|Brauer|1935}} and was continued by him for the next few decades.

== Example ==

Finding a representation of the [[cyclic group]] of two elements over '''F'''<sub>2</sub> is equivalent to the problem of finding matrices whose square is the identity matrix.  Over every field of characteristic other than 2, there is always a basis such that the matrix can be written as a diagonal matrix with only 1 or −1 occurring on the diagonal, such as

:<math>
\begin{bmatrix}
1 & 0\\
0 & -1
\end{bmatrix}.
</math>

Over '''F'''<sub>2</sub>, there are many other possible matrices, such as

:<math>
\begin{bmatrix}
1 & 1\\
0 & 1
\end{bmatrix}.
</math>

Over an algebraically closed field of positive characteristic,
the representation theory of a finite cyclic group is fully explained
by the theory of the [[Jordan normal form]]. Non-diagonal Jordan
forms occur when the characteristic divides the order of the group.

== Ring theory interpretation ==

Given a field ''K'' and a finite group ''G'', the [[group algebra]] ''K''[''G''] (which is the ''K''-vector space
with ''K''-basis consisting of the elements of ''G'', endowed with
algebra multiplication by extending the multiplication
of ''G'' by linearity) is an [[Artinian ring]].

When the order of ''G'' is divisible by the characteristic of ''K'',  the group algebra is not [[Semisimple algebraic group|semisimple]], hence has non-zero [[Jacobson radical]]. In that case, there are finite-dimensional modules for the group algebra that are not [[projective module]]s. By contrast, in the characteristic 0 case every [[irreducible representation]] is a [[direct summand]] of the [[regular representation]], hence is projective.

==Brauer characters==
Modular representation theory was developed by [[Richard Brauer]] from about 1940 onwards to study in greater depth the relationships between the
characteristic ''p'' representation theory, ordinary character theory and structure of ''G'', especially  as the latter relates to the embedding of, and relationships between, its ''p''-subgroups. Such results can be applied in [[group theory]] to problems not directly phrased in terms of representations.

Brauer introduced the notion now known as the '''Brauer character'''. When ''K'' is algebraically closed of positive characteristic ''p'', there is a bijection between roots of unity in ''K'' and complex roots of unity of order prime to ''p''. Once a choice of such a  bijection is fixed, the Brauer character of a representation assigns to each group element of order coprime to ''p'' the sum of complex roots of unity corresponding to the eigenvalues  (including multiplicities) of that element in the given representation.

The Brauer character of a representation determines its composition
factors but not, in general, its equivalence type. The irreducible
Brauer characters are those afforded by the simple modules.
These are integral (though not necessarily non-negative) combinations
of the restrictions to elements of order coprime to ''p'' of the ordinary irreducible
characters. Conversely, the restriction to the elements of order prime to ''p'' of
each ordinary irreducible character is uniquely expressible as a non-negative
integer combination of irreducible Brauer characters.

==Reduction (mod ''p'')==
In the theory initially developed by Brauer, the link between ordinary representation theory and modular representation theory is best exemplified by considering the
[[group algebra]] of the group ''G'' over a complete discrete
valuation ring ''R'' with residue field ''K'' of positive
characteristic ''p'' and field of fractions ''F'' of characteristic
0, such as the [[p-adic integers]]. The structure of ''R''[''G''] is closely related both to
the structure of the group algebra ''K''[''G''] and to the structure of the semisimple group algebra  ''F''[''G''], and there is much interplay
between the module theory of the three algebras.

Each ''R''[''G'']-module naturally gives rise to an ''F''[''G'']-module,
and, by a process often known informally as '''reduction (mod p)''',
to a ''K''[''G'']-module. On the other hand, since ''R'' is a
[[principal ideal domain]], each finite-dimensional ''F''[''G'']-module
arises by extension of scalars from an ''R''[''G'']-module. In general,
however, not all ''K''[''G'']-modules arise as reductions (mod p) of
''R''[''G'']-modules. Those that do are '''liftable'''.

== Number of simple modules ==

In ordinary representation theory, the number of simple modules ''k''(''G'') is equal to the number of [[conjugacy class]]es of ''G''. In the modular case, the number ''l''(''G'') of simple modules is equal to the number of conjugacy classes whose elements have order coprime to the relevant prime ''p'', the so-called ''p''-regular classes.

== Blocks and the structure of the group algebra ==

In modular representation theory, while Maschke's theorem does not hold
when the characteristic divides the group order, the group algebra may be decomposed as the direct sum of a maximal collection of two-sided ideals known as '''blocks'''. When the field ''F'' has characteristic 0, or characteristic coprime to the group order, there is still such a decomposition of the  group algebra ''F''[''G''] as a sum of blocks (one for each isomorphism type of simple module), but the situation is relatively transparent when ''F'' is sufficiently large: each block is a full matrix algebra over ''F'', the endomorphism ring of the vector space underlying the associated simple module.

To obtain the blocks, the identity element of the group ''G'' is decomposed as a sum of primitive [[idempotent]]s
in ''Z''(''R''[G]),  the center of the group algebra over the maximal order ''R'' of ''F''. The block corresponding to the primitive idempotent
''e'' is the two-sided ideal ''e'' ''R''[''G'']. For each indecomposable ''R''[''G'']-module, there is only one such primitive idempotent that does not annihilate it, and the module is said to belong to (or to be in)  the corresponding block (in which case, all its [[composition factor]]s also belong to that block). In particular, each simple module belongs to a unique block. Each ordinary irreducible character may also be assigned to a unique block according to its decomposition as a sum of irreducible Brauer characters. The block containing the [[trivial representation|trivial module]] is known as the '''principal block'''.

== Projective modules ==

In ordinary representation theory, every indecomposable module is irreducible, and so every module is projective. However, the simple modules with characteristic dividing the group order are rarely projective. Indeed, if a simple module is projective, then it is the only simple module in its block, which is then isomorphic to the endomorphism algebra of the underlying vector space, a full matrix algebra. In that case, the block is said to have 'defect 0'. Generally, the structure of projective modules is difficult to determine.

For the group algebra of a finite group, the (isomorphism types of) projective indecomposable modules are in a one-to-one correspondence with the (isomorphism types of) simple modules: the [[Socle (mathematics)|socle]] of each projective indecomposable is simple (and isomorphic to the top), and this affords the bijection, as non-isomorphic projective indecomposables have
non-isomorphic socles. The multiplicity of a projective indecomposable module as a summand of the group algebra (viewed as the regular module) is the dimension of its socle (for large enough fields of characteristic zero, this recovers the fact that each simple module occurs with multiplicity equal to its dimension as a direct summand of the regular module).

Each projective indecomposable module (and hence each projective module) in positive characteristic ''p'' may be lifted to a module in characteristic 0. Using the ring ''R'' as above, with residue field ''K'', the identity element of ''G'' may be decomposed as a sum of mutually orthogonal primitive [[idempotent]]s (not necessarily
central) of ''K''[''G'']. Each projective indecomposable ''K''[''G'']-module is isomorphic to  ''e''.''K''[''G''] for a primitive idempotent ''e'' that occurs in this decomposition. The idempotent ''e'' lifts to a primitive idempotent, say ''E'', of ''R''[''G''], and the left module ''E''.''R''[''G''] has reduction (mod p) isomorphic to ''e''.''K''[''G''].

==Some orthogonality relations for Brauer characters==
When  a projective module is lifted, the associated character vanishes on all elements of order divisible by ''p'', and (with consistent choice of roots of unity), agrees with the Brauer character of the original characteristic ''p'' module on ''p''-regular elements. The (usual character-ring) inner product of the Brauer character of a projective indecomposable with any other Brauer character can thus be defined: this is 0 if the
second Brauer character is that of the socle of a non-isomorphic projective indecomposable, and 1
if the second Brauer character is that of its own socle. The multiplicity of an ordinary irreducible
character in the character of the lift of a projective indecomposable is equal to the number
of occurrences of the Brauer character of the socle of the projective indecomposable when the restriction of the ordinary character to ''p''-regular elements is expressed as a sum of irreducible Brauer characters.

==Decomposition matrix and Cartan matrix==

The [[composition series|composition factors]] of the projective indecomposable modules may be calculated as follows:
Given the ordinary irreducible and irreducible Brauer characters of a particular finite group, the irreducible [[ordinary character]]s may be decomposed as non-negative integer combinations of the irreducible Brauer characters. The integers involved can be placed in a matrix, with the ordinary irreducible characters assigned rows and the irreducible Brauer characters assigned columns. This is referred to as the ''[[decomposition matrix]]'', and is frequently labelled ''D''. It is customary to place the trivial ordinary and Brauer characters in the first row and column respectively. The product of the transpose of ''D'' with ''D'' itself
results in the [[Cartan matrix]], usually denoted ''C''; this is a symmetric matrix such that the entries in its ''j''-th row are the multiplicities of the respective simple modules as composition
factors of the ''j''-th projective indecomposable module. The Cartan
matrix is non-singular; in fact, its determinant is a power of the
characteristic of ''K''.

Since a projective indecomposable module in a given block has
all its composition factors in that same block, each block has
its own Cartan matrix.

== Defect groups ==

To each block ''B'' of the group algebra ''K''[''G''], Brauer associated a certain ''p''-subgroup, known as its '''defect group''' (where ''p'' is the characteristic of ''K''). Formally, it is the largest ''p''-subgroup
''D'' of ''G'' for which there is a [[Brauer's three main theorems|Brauer correspondent]] of ''B'' for the
subgroup <math>DC_G(D)</math>, where <math>C_G(D)</math> is the [[centralizer]] of ''D'' in ''G''.

The defect group of a block is unique up to conjugacy and has a strong influence on the structure of the block. For example, if the defect group is trivial, then the block contains just one simple module, just one ordinary character, the ordinary and Brauer irreducible characters agree on elements of order prime to the relevant characteristic ''p'', and the simple module is projective. At the other extreme, when ''K'' has characteristic ''p'', the [[Sylow]] ''p''-subgroup of the finite group ''G'' is a defect group for the principal block of ''K''[''G''].

The order of the defect group of a block has many arithmetical characterizations related to representation theory. It is the largest invariant factor of the Cartan matrix of the block, and occurs with
multiplicity one. Also, the power of ''p'' dividing the index of the defect group of a block is the [[greatest common divisor]] of the powers of ''p'' dividing the dimensions of the simple modules in that block, and this coincides with the greatest common divisor of the powers of ''p'' dividing the degrees of the ordinary irreducible characters in that block.

Other relationships between the defect group of a block and character theory include Brauer's result that if no conjugate of the ''p''-part of a group element ''g'' is in the defect group of a given block, then each irreducible character in that block vanishes at ''g''. This is one of many consequences of Brauer's second main theorem.

The defect group of a block also has several characterizations in the more module-theoretic approach to block theory, building on the work of [[Sandy Green (mathematician)|J. A. Green]], which associates a ''p''-subgroup
known as the '''vertex''' to an indecomposable module, defined in terms  of '''relative projectivity''' of the module. For example, the vertex of each indecomposable module in a block is contained (up to conjugacy)
in the defect group of the block, and no proper subgroup of the defect group has that property.

Brauer's first main theorem states that the number of blocks of a finite group that have a given ''p''-subgroup as defect group is the same as the corresponding number for the normalizer in the group of that ''p''-subgroup.

The easiest block structure to analyse with non-trivial defect group is when the latter is cyclic. Then there are only finitely many isomorphism types of indecomposable modules in the block, and the structure of the block is by now well understood, by virtue of work of Brauer, [[E.C. Dade]], J.A.Green and [[John Griggs Thompson|J.G.Thompson]], among others. In all other cases, there are infinitely many isomorphism types of indecomposable modules in the block.

Blocks whose defect groups are not cyclic can be divided into two types: tame and wild. The tame blocks (which only occur for the prime 2) have as a defect group a [[dihedral group]], [[semidihedral group]] or (generalized) [[quaternion group]], and their structure has been broadly determined in a series of papers by [[Karin Erdmann]]. The indecomposable modules in wild blocks are extremely difficult to classify, even in principle.
